case_name: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. K. K. Raghavan

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 28, 1960 of the Industrial Tribunal, Ernakulam, in Industrial Dispute No. 81 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 28, 1960 of the Industrial Tribunal, Ernakulam, in Industrial Dispute No. 81 of 1958.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 517 of 1963 before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 51.7 of 1963.

facts.text: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. dismissed workman K. K. Raghavan with effect from November 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: the validity of the order passed by the Industrial Tribunal, Ernakulam, directing the appellant, the Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd., to reinstate its workman K. K. Raghavan whom it had dismissed with effect from the 14th of November, 1955.

facts.text: On November 12, 1955, Mr. Raghavan and Mr. Mathews waylaid and assaulted Mr. C. A. Augustine while he was returning home after duty.

anchor.surface_text: It was reported to the appellant that on the 12th November, 1955, Mr. Raghavan and another employee of the appellant, Mr. Mathews by name, waylaid Mr. C. A. Augustine, the Chargeman of the Soap Plant of the companys factory at Tatapuram while he was returning home after his duty in the second shift and assaulted him.

facts.text: Charge-sheets issued against Raghavan and Mathews on November 14, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: That is why charge-sheets were issued against both Messrs Raghavan and Mathews on the 14th November, 1955.

facts.text: Enquiry held by Mr. Y. D. Joshi from December 27 to 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the General Manager of the appellant appointed Mr. Y. D. Joshi, who is a Law Officer of the appellant in the Head Office, to hold the enquiry. Mr. Joshi held the enquiry from the 27th to 30th December, 1955,

facts.text: Enquiry Officer Mr. Joshi made report on January 7, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and subsequently, he made his report to the General Manager of the appellant on the 7th January, 1956.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal approved dismissal of Raghavan but not Mathews.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal approved of the dismissal of Raghavan, but did number accord its approval of the dismissal of Mathews.

facts.text: Industrial dispute reference ordered on December 3, 1958 regarding dismissal of Raghavan.

anchor.surface_text: Not satisfied with the order of dismissal, the respondent raised an industrial dispute in regard to the propriety and validity of the said dismissal of Raghavan and that has become the subject-matter of the present reference which was ordered on the 3rd of December, 1958.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal ordered reinstatement of Raghavan on September 28, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It is on this reference that the Industrial tribunal has held that the appellant was number justified in dismissing Raghavan, and so, has ordered his reinstatement.

facts.text: Assault occurred outside the factory at a considerable distance.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the alleged assault took place outside the factory, and, in fact, at a companysiderable distance from it.

facts.text: Assault motivated by hostility over Incentive Bonus Scheme; Raghavan opposed it, Augustine supported.

anchor.surface_text: Now, when we look at the report of the Enquiry Officer, it is clear that on the evidence given by Mr. M. M. Augustine and K. T. Joseph it appeared that the assault was companymitted by Raghavan on C. A. Augustine, because he was in favour of the introduction of the Incentive Bonus Scheme.

facts.text: Raghavan wanted to examine witnesses M. P. Menon and Chalakudi during enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: The whole of this companytention is based on the fact that Raghavan wanted to examine two witnesses, -Messrs M. P. Menon and Chalakudi.

facts.text: Enquiry Officer wrote letters to witnesses M.P. Menon and Chalakudi to assist Raghavan.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, in order to assist Raghavan, the Enquiry Officer wrote letters to the two witnesses.

facts.text: M.P. Menon replied unable to attend.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Menon replied expressing his inability to be present before the Enquiry Officer,

facts.text: Chalakudi sent unsigned letter received on December 31, 1955, no action taken.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to Chalakudi, it appears that he sent one letter addressed to the Enquiry Officer and it reached him on the 31st December, 1955, the day on which he was leaving for Bombay. This letter was number signed,

facts.text: Tribunal found no victimization or unfair labour practice.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the plea of victimisation, the Tribunal has definitely found against the respondent. I do number for a moment believe, says the Tribunal, that the management foisted a case against the ex-worker. Regarding the allegation of victimisation, there is numbersufficient evidence

facts.text: Criminal proceedings started against Raghavan.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal appears to have taken the view that since criminal proceedings had been started against Raghavan,

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 31, 1964 by Gajendragadkar C.J.

anchor.surface_text: March 31, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR, C. J.-This appeal by special leave raises a short question about the validity of the order passed

facts.text: Appellant owns factory at Tatapuram, Ernakulam, Kerala; Raghavan worked there.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a public limited companycern engaged in the industry of soaps and toilet articles. It owns three factories in addition to 12 sales offices. One of these factories is located at Tatapuram, Ernakulam, in the State of Kerala. Mr. Raghavan was working with the appellant at its factory at Tatapuram.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Tribunal's order and answers reference in favour of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed. The order passed by the Industrial Tribunal is set aside and the reference made to it is answered in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant offered ex gratia Rs. 1000 to Raghavan.

anchor.surface_text: Before we part with this appeal, we ought to add that Mr. Pai for the appellant has fairly offered to pay ex gratia Rs. 1,000/- to Raghavan in addition to the amount which has already been paid to him by the appellant
Appeal by special leave from the Award dated September 28, 1960 of the Industrial Tribunal, Ernakulam, in Industrial Dispute No. 81 of 1958.

Standing Order 22 viii  of the Certified Standing Orders of the appellant. The said standing order provides that without prejudice to the general meaning of the term misconduct, it shall be deemed to mean and include, inter alia, drunkenness, fighting, riotous or disorderly or indecent behaviour within or without the factory.

concepts.interpretation: Includes riotous or disorderly behaviour without the factory if it has rational connection with employment; not limited to purely private disputes.

issues.text: whether the Tribunal was right in holding that the facts proved against Raghavan did number attract the provisions of Standing Order 22 viii  of the Certified Standing Orders of the appellant

anchor.surface_text: The first point which calls for our decision in this appeal is whether the Tribunal was right in holding that the facts proved against Raghavan did number attract the provisions of Standing Order 22 viii  of the Certified Standing Orders of the appellant.

issues.text: whether the Tribunal was justified in holding that the Enquiry Officer did number conduct the enquiry in accordance with the principles of natural justice, and so, the Tribunal was entitled to go into the evidence itself and decide whether, Raghavans dismissal was justified or number

anchor.surface_text: principles of natural justice, and so, the Tribunal was entitled to go into the evidence itself and decide whether, Raghavans dismissal was justified or number.

anchor.surface_text: Let us then consider whether the dismissal of Raghavan is actuated by malafides, or amounts to victimisation.

issues.text: in cases where the employee is unable to lead his evidence before the domestic Tribunal for no fault of his own, a similar opportunity should be given to him to prove his case in proceedings before the Industrial Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: even if a domestic enquiry is found to be defective, the employer may seek to justify the dismissal of his employee by leading evidence before the Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: criminal proceedings had been started against Raghavan, the domestic enquiry should have been stayed pending the final disposal of the said criminal proceedings.

arguments.claim: The facts proved against Raghavan did not attract Standing Order 22 viii because the assault was a purely private matter between Raghavan and Augustine

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal has held that the assault in question can be treated as a purely private matter between Raghavan and Augustine with which the appellant was not concerned and as a result of which standing order 22 viii cannot be invoked against Raghavan.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s a result of which standing order 22 viii  cannot be invoked against Raghavan. Mr. Menon who has appeared for the respondent before us, has companyte

arguments.court_reasoning: Assault motivated by hostility over Incentive Bonus Scheme, creating rational connection with employment

arguments.claim: In construing standing orders, disputes of a purely private or individual type should not be brought within their scope

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Menon who has appeared for the respondent before us, has contended that in construing standing orders of this character, we must take care to see that disputes of a purely private or individual type are not brought within their scope. He argues that on many occasions, individual employees may have to deal with private disputes

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he alleged assault took place outside the factory, and, in fact, at a companysiderable distance from it. The Tribunal has held that the assault in que

arguments.court_reasoning: Well-founded generally for purely private disputes without rational connection to employment, but not applicable here

arguments.claim: Standing Order 22 viii is attracted only if disorderly or riotous behaviour outside factory has rational connection with employment

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this contention is well-founded. It would, we think, be unreasonable to include within standing order 22 viii any riotous behaviour without the factory which was the result of purely private and individual dispute and in course of which tempers of both the contestants became hot.

arguments.claim: Assault committed because Augustine supported Incentive Bonus Scheme, motivated by union rivalry, hence rational connection to employment

Joseph it appeared that the assault was committed by Raghavan on C. A. Augustine, because he was in favour of the introduction of the Incentive Bonus Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal was justified in holding that the Enquiry Officer did not conduct the enquiry in accordance with the principles of natural justice, and so, the Tribunal was entitled to go into the evidence itself and decide whether, Raghavans dismissal was justified or not.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not required to act on unsigned letter; employee failed to produce witnesses

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, thought that because the Enquiry Officer did not give an adjournment to Raghavan to examine his witnesses, that introduced an element of malafides. It has also observed that since the case against Raghavan did not fall within the purview of standing order 22 viii

arguments.court_reasoning: No justification for blaming officer on adjournment; mere erroneous conclusion not malafides

arguments.claim: Even if domestic enquiry defective, mere error of conclusion of fact or law does not constitute malafides

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the Tribunal has completely overlooked an elementary principle of judicial approach that even if a judge or Tribunal may reach an erroneous conclusion either of fact or of law, the mere error of the conclusion does not make the conclusion malafides.

arguments.claim: By parity of reasoning with Phulbari Tea Estate, if employee unable to lead evidence before domestic tribunal through no fault, should get opportunity before Industrial Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Menon contends that by parity of reasoning, in cases where the employee is unable to lead his evidence before the domestic Tribunal for no fault of his own, a similar opportunity should be given to him to prove his case in proceedings before the Industrial Tribunal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed, of companyrse, he leads evidence before the Industrial Tribunal and persuades the Tribunal to accept his case. That, however, is very -different f

arguments.court_reasoning: No parity; fair enquiry findings binding unless perverse; employee had opportunity but failed to use it

arguments.claim: Findings of fair domestic enquiry are binding on Industrial Tribunal unless perverse or unsupported by evidence

anchor.surface_text: The decision in the case of Phulbari Tea Estate supra proceeds on the basis which is of basic importance in industrial adjudication that findings properly recorded in domestic enquiries which are conducted fairly, cannot be re-examined by Industrial adjudication unless the said findings are either perverse,

arguments.claim: Domestic enquiry should have been stayed pending criminal proceedings against Raghavan

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal appears to have taken the view that since criminal proceedings had been started against Raghavan, the domestic enquiry should have been stayed pending the final disposal of the said criminal proceedings.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anysidering the merits of the dispute for itself in the present reference proceedings. Since the enquiry has been fairly companyducted, and the findin

arguments.court_reasoning: Desirable especially for grave charges, but not mandatory; does not vitiate enquiry

arguments.claim: It is desirable to stay domestic enquiry pending criminal trial for grave charges, but not mandatory and proceeding without stay does not vitiate

anchor.surface_text: As this Court has held in the Delhi Cloth and General Mills Ltd. v. Kushal Bhan, it is desirable that if the incident giving rise to a charge framed against a workman in a domestic enquiry is being tried in a criminal court, the employer, should stay the domestic enquiry pending the final disposal of the criminal case.

holdings.text: In order that standing order 22 viii may be attracted, the appellant should be able to show that the disorderly or riotous behaviour had some rational connection with the employment of the assailant and the victim.

anchor.surface_text: In order that standing order 22 viii may be attracted, the appellant should be able to show that the disorderly or riotous behaviour had some rational connection with the employment of the assailant and the victim.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation limits scope to behaviour with rational connection to employment, excluding purely private disputes.

holdings.text: The assault committed by Raghavan on Augustine was not a purely private or individual matter but motivated by hostility over the Incentive Bonus Scheme, attracting standing order 22 viii.

anchor.surface_text: Now, when we look at the report of the Enquiry Officer, it is clear that on the evidence given by Mr. M. M. Augustine and K. T. Joseph it appeared that the assault was committed by Raghavan on C. A. Augustine, because he was in favour of the introduction of the Incentive Bonus Scheme.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry Officer's findings based on evidence show motive linked to union rivalry and production scheme, creating nexus to employment.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was in error in coming to the conclusion that the enquiry suffered from the infirmity that it was conducted contrary to the principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the Tribunal was in error in coming to the conclusion that the enquiry suffered from the infirmity that it was conducted contrary to the principles of natural justice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry Officer assisted by summoning witnesses; employee failed to produce them timely; no duty to compel attendance or act on unsigned letter.

holdings.text: The finding of the Tribunal that the dismissal of Raghavan was malafide, cannot possibly be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the finding of the Tribunal that the dismissal of Raghavan was malafide, cannot possibly be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Erroneous conclusions of fact or law do not constitute malafides; no basis for blaming Enquiry Officer on adjournment or charge framing.

holdings.text: The Tribunal has definitely found against the respondent on victimisation, and this finding is quite clearly in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the plea of victimisation, the Tribunal has definitely found against the respondent. I do not for a moment believe, says the Tribunal, that the management foisted a case against the ex-worker.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts Tribunal's own finding of no victimisation or unfair labour practice; insufficient evidence.

holdings.text: We are not prepared to accede to Mr. Menons argument that the Tribunal was justified in considering the merits of the dispute for itself in the present reference proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are not prepared to accede to Mr. Menons argument that the Tribunal was justified in considering the merits of the dispute for itself in the present reference proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fair domestic enquiry findings binding unless perverse; no parity with employer leading evidence post-defective enquiry; employee had opportunity but failed.

holdings.text: Findings properly recorded at such enquiries are binding on the parties, unless, of course, it is known that the said findings are perverse, or are not based on any evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Findings properly recorded at such enquiries are binding on the parties, unless, of course, it is known that the said findings are perverse, or are not based on any evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirms Phulbari Tea Estate principle on binding nature of fair domestic enquiries in industrial adjudication.

holdings.text: But to say that domestic enquiries may be stayed pending criminal trial is very different from saying that if an employer proceeds with the domestic enquiry in spite of the fact that the criminal trial is pending, the enquiry for that reason alone is vitiated and the conclusion reached in such an enquiry is either bad in law or malafide.

anchor.surface_text: But to say that domestic enquiries may be stayed pending criminal trial is very different from saying that if an employer proceeds with the domestic enquiry in spite of the fact that the criminal trial is pending, the enquiry for that reason alone is vitiated and the conclusion reached in such an enquiry is either bad in law or malafide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Desirable per Delhi Cloth case, especially for grave charges, but not mandatory; no vitiation if proceeded without stay.

holdings.text: We accordingly hold that the domestic enquiry in this case was properly held and fairly conducted and the conclusions of fact reached by the Enquiry Officer are based on evidence which he accepted as true. That being so, it was not open to the Industrial Tribunal to reconsider the same questions of fact and come to a contrary conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the domestic enquiry in this case was properly held and fairly conducted and the conclusions of fact reached by the Enquiry Officer are based on evidence which he accepted as true. That being so, it was not open to the Industrial Tribunal to reconsider the same questions of fact and come to a contrary conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of all issues: enquiry fair, SO applies, no malafides, findings binding; Tribunal cannot re-appraise.

anchor.surface_text: In order that standing order 22 viii may be attracted, the appellant should be able to show that the disorderly or riotous behaviour had some rational connection with the employment of the assailant and the victim.
The result is, the appeal is allowed. The order passed by the Industrial Tribunal is set aside and the reference made to it is answered in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Now, when we look at the report of the Enquiry Officer, it is clear that on the evidence given by Mr. M. M. Augustine and K. T. Joseph it appeared that the assault was committed by Raghavan on C. A. Augustine, because he was in favour of the introduction of the Incentive Bonus Scheme.
The result is, the appeal is allowed. The order passed by the Industrial Tribunal is set aside and the reference made to it is answered in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the plea of victimisation, the Tribunal has definitely found against the respondent. I do not for a moment believe, says the Tribunal, that the management foisted a case against the ex-worker.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are not prepared to accede to Mr. Menons argument that the Tribunal was justified in considering the merits of the dispute for itself in the present reference proceedings.
The result is, the appeal is allowed. The order passed by the Industrial Tribunal is set aside and the reference made to it is answered in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Findings properly recorded at such enquiries are binding on the parties, unless, of course, it is known that the said findings are perverse, or are not based on any evidence.
The result is, the appeal is allowed. The order passed by the Industrial Tribunal is set aside and the reference made to it is answered in favour of the appellant.

edges.explanation: Holding supports concept by affirming that enquiries may be stayed (desirable) but proceeding without does not vitiate, aligning with non-mandatory aspect
Holding addresses issue by clarifying that not staying does not invalidate, countering strict stay requirement

anchor.surface_text: But to say that domestic enquiries may be stayed pending criminal trial is very different from saying that if an employer proceeds with the domestic enquiry in spite of the fact that the criminal trial is pending, the enquiry for that reason alone is vitiated and the conclusion reached in such an enquiry is either bad in law or malafide.
The result is, the appeal is allowed. The order passed by the Industrial Tribunal is set aside and the reference made to it is answered in favour of the appellant.
The result is, the appeal is allowed. The order passed by the Industrial Tribunal is set aside and the reference made to it is answered in favour of the appellant.
